lines.text: Well, then take your mask off.
Oh, no. I couldn't do that. I haven't got anything on underneath it.
Your lips are fire.
I know. Saves a fortune on matches. Don't turn in the alarm.
Don't be frightened, Francesca. I'm scared enough for all of us.
[frequently repeated phrase]
Farffel farffel pippick.

[introducing Francesca on the fly]
This is... his, um... um, his first cousin.
First by a mile!
15 gondola!

[Hearing her family trying to get in to save her honor]
Run! Hide!
Casanova never runs, but he hides!
[the Doge formally toasts Casanova]

[Whispering warningly so that others at the table don't here]
Don't toast YOURSELF!
The wine's free and I'm thirsty!

[Whispering in his ear again]
Mind your manners!
Oh, please stop nibbling on my ear. Don't let this beauty mark fool you, too.
This is Lucio, my food taster.
Your food taster?
Yes. You can't get good food tasters these days. The slightest hint of poison and they quit!

[after laughter]
Lucio is my cousin's ninth food taster.
Tenth, counting Mother.

[to Maggioni]
Oh, please, spare my miserable life! I'll work off the debt! I'll make more wine for you. I've got big feet! What grapes I can't trample on I can sit on!
What's Casanova got that, if I had, I probably couldn't handle anyway?
Pippo, I need your horse. He isn't much but he's better then running down the road on foot.
Run?
Shh!
But why should My Lord run? Everybody's waiting in the kitchen to get paid.
Exactly why, my friend. I haven't a ducat.
Casanova penniless? Oh, but you owe them a fortune. They'll be bankrupt.
I know. It's very sad. The whole time I am running, there will be tears in my eyes.

[selecting a merchant to play Casanova]
You! You will be Casanova.
Me? But I have seventeen children.
Well, that's recommendation enough.

[finding it difficult to believe Pippo is Casanova]
Uh, you were described to us as, uh, regal, handsome, intelligent, virile, uh...
That's good enough for mixed company, but then, after all, none of us look too good in the morning, especially after a night out - and what a night I had out.
Signora Bruni, there is nothing in Casanova's technique I have not seen through keyholes or heard through closed doors.
Casanova, in person?
In person, in love, and in a hurry. Kiss me!
[Pippo embraces Maria fiercely]
Oh, sir, you're too impetuous.
I have to work fast. Venice is a big city. I'm getting to the age where I can only work a couple of canals a day.
But there should always be some polite conversation first.
Well, if you insist on formalities - "Delightful weather we're having." Conversation over. Kiss me!
I have been a great lover for over twenty years, man and boy. The boy's worn out, but the man...? Hm! Ask any woman in Italy.
Oh, now, let's make a deal. I won't kill any of you if you don't kill any of me.
Signor Casanova, you do Venice a great honor by your visit.
Oh, it's nothing. I like to spread it around.
Oh, you look so pretty. I can't think of anybody I'd rather have my throat cut with.
Hiding behind a woman's skirts, huh?
That's what YOU'RE doing!
I knew it was ONE of us.
Oh, and by the way, leave your name and address with my valet. If I can't call you, maybe he will. He's skinny but fun.
Women are like oranges. You've squeezed one, you've squeezed them all.
What time is it?
About seventeen-fifty-eight.
You only have one life.
If you work it right, one is enough.
I can't let her down. I'd never be able to look another needle in the eye.
[last lines]

[Bob Hope as himself]
What's the matter with this theater? Don't they sell popcorn?
Goodbye, Casanova. You're a very gallant gentleman. You have loved many women but I am your greatest conquest of all for I shall remember you like this for the rest of my life.
